Latest Updates https://www.economist.com/latest/ The most recent blogs and online articles from The Economist - Made with love by RSSHub(https://github.com/DIYgod/RSSHub) RS集线器i@diygod.me (DIYgod) zh-cn 2023 年 7 月 19 日星期三 00:38:37 GMT 120 Why Africa is poised to become a big player in energy markets

能源市场正受到前所未有的双重打击。自去年俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来，欧洲削减了从俄罗斯的能源进口。俄罗斯是世界第二大天然气生产国和第三大石油生产国。两者的价格均先上涨后回落，但人们对能源安全的担忧依然存在。与此同时，气候变化正在促使石油等化石燃料以及最终的天然气发生深刻但不确定的转变。面对这些挑战，欧洲的政治家和实业家担心如何保持工厂运转和家庭温暖。

非洲可能是解决欧洲当前天然气问题和长期碳问题的答案。它拥有占全球13%的天然气储量（仅略低于中东）、占全球7%的石油以及巨大的绿色能源潜力。意大利石油巨头埃尼集团首席执行官克劳迪奥·德斯卡尔齐表示，非洲能源可能“成为欧洲未来的真正核心——而不仅仅是欧洲”。 “他们有很多——很多——天然气，他们有阳光、风……[这]对我们的能源转型来说是完美的。”

这番话并非空话。包括埃尼集团在内的国际能源公司正在重新启动或制定新计划，在非洲大陆生产液化天然气 ( lng )。其中包括重启两个被搁置的大型液化天然气项目，其中一个位于坦桑尼亚，价值300亿至400亿美元，另一个价值200亿美元，位于莫桑比克。

这一活动标志着过去几十年来普遍情绪的急剧变化，当时非洲对能源市场的重要性已经下降。这个大陆曾经提供了世界国际贸易液化天然气的五分之一，现在提供了一半的份额。其在全球石油和煤炭产量中所占的份额也有所下降，尤其是石油投资者因尼日利亚（通常是非洲大陆最大生产国）安全局势恶化而推迟投资。

更高的价格、随着欧盟从俄罗斯转向多元化以及从煤炭转向天然气（一种更清洁的燃料），欧洲需求增加，正在推动这一变化。而且摆动的速度很快。莫桑比克于 11 月运送了第一批液化天然气，并且可能很快会出口更多。法国石油巨头 TotalEnergies 可能很快会在莫桑比克重新启动一个大型液化天然气项目，该项目曾因圣战叛乱而于 2021 年停止。 TotalEnergies首席执行官帕特里克·普扬内 (Patrick Pouyanné) 告诉《经济学人》 ，该项目已基本重回正轨，因此应该会在 2028 年之前开始生产天然气。安全性的提高也可能会提振附近由埃克森美孚 (Exxon Mobil) 提议的更大液化天然气项目的前景。西方最大的石油巨头中国石油天然气集团公司。在邻近的坦桑尼亚边境，两家欧洲能源公司壳牌和 Equinor 正在重启其拟议的 300 亿至 400 亿美元液化天然气项目。

此外，塞内加尔和毛里塔尼亚的液化天然气项目预计将于今年投产，二期工程前景看好。非洲最大的液化天然气出口国尼日利亚的产能到 2026 年应增加约 35%。

哥伦比亚大学的 Akos Losz 估计，到 2030 年，撒哈拉以南非洲地区的新天然气项目总共可增加约 900 亿立方米的液化天然气年产能。可以肯定的是，只有大约五分之一的容量已经在建设中，或者出于安全原因没有被搁置，有些项目可能仍会失败。然而能源公司似乎决心继续前进。 Losz 先生认为，埃尼公司刚刚签署了一项价值 80 亿美元的开发利比亚两个油田协议的北非新项目，到 2030 年可额外供应 30 bcm 的天然气。研究公司 Rystad Energy 也看到了类似的潜力（见图表）。如果一切顺利进行，即使考虑到卡塔尔预计将大幅增加产量，非洲当前产量将增加 120 bcm，其在全球天然气产量中所占的份额将从目前的 6% 提高到 8.5%。仅非洲的额外产量就足以抵消 2021 年至 2022 年间俄罗斯对欧盟天然气出口下降 70 bcm 的影响。

从长远来看，非洲似乎将在能源市场中发挥更大的作用。全球天然气出口国俱乐部天然气出口国论坛预计，非洲新增天然气产能将超过除中东以外的任何其他地区。据估计，到 2050 年，非洲每年的产量将达到近 600 bcm，而目前的产量为 249 bcm。

计算装备，而不是装备数量

其他指标似乎也支持这些乐观的预测。 Rystad 表示，作为勘探和生产的领先指标，非洲运营的钻井数量达到 2019 年以来的最高水平。今年非洲勘探和开发支出预计将达到 460 亿美元，为 2017 年以来的最高水平。与此同时，另一家能源研究公司 Wood Mackenzie 表示，自 2014 年以来，非洲在全球天然气资本支出中所占的份额已增加一倍多。

石油也正在吸引投资。全球第三大国际石油和天然气公司TotalEnergies今年将把其全球勘探预算的一半用于纳米比亚，那里可能蕴藏着多达110亿桶的石油和潜在的天然气。这可能使纳米比亚成为一个巨大的生产国。 “我们毫不怀疑这将会发生，”纳米比亚能源部长汤姆·阿尔温多 (Tom Alweendo) 表示。即使是少量的碳氢化合物出口也会对贫穷国家产生重大影响。以尼日尔为例，中国建造的出口管道即将完工。尼日尔总统穆罕默德·巴祖姆表示：“仅明年一年，它所带来的预算资源就相当于我们当前预算的四分之一。” “接下来的几年它会更大。”

非洲也有成为绿色能源生产大国的巨大潜力。尽管它拥有阳光明媚、广阔的沙漠、多风的海岸和平原以及喷涌的河流，但它一直是一个落后者，其太阳能和风能装机容量仅占世界的1%，水电装机容量仅占世界的4%。这种情况也在发生变化，尽管速度可能还不够快：自 2016 年以来，非洲太阳能装机容量几乎翻了两番。

非洲之所以表现不佳，主要是因为它很难出口绿色能源。投资主要用于当地电力消耗（占世界电力总量的不到3%），甚至私营电力生产商也常常难以赚钱，因为它们通过效率低下的国有公用事业供应小市场。

现在，新技术可以让可再生能源生产商通过出口能源来回避国内市场的问题。凭借有保证的出口收入，绿色能源公司可以更轻松地获得建设大型高效工厂所需的投资。溢出效应之一是它们还应该能够为当地经济提供电力。

第一个出口机会是通过生产所谓的“绿色氢”，它是通过使用可再生电力将水分解为氧气和氢气而制成的。富裕国家将绿色氢视为保持其能源密集型工业运转并同时削减碳排放的最佳希望。美国最近推出了世界上最大的低碳氢补贴（包括通过天然气和碳捕获生产的氢）。欧盟的新能源计划旨在使欧盟不再依赖俄罗斯化石燃料，该计划为欧洲设定了目标，即到 2030 年每年生产 1000 万吨绿色氢，并再进口 1000 万吨。 Tank估计，如果要在本世纪中叶实现净零排放的目标，到2030年，世界将需要每年生产9000万吨低碳氢，到2050年，每年需要生产4.5亿吨低碳氢。

非洲强大的太阳能和风能潜力使其成为生产绿色氢的有吸引力的地方。欧盟的开发银行欧洲投资银行（ EIB ）最近进行的一项研究认为，到2035年，非洲每年可以从三个区域生产5000万吨的东西：埃及；毛里塔尼亚和摩洛哥；以及纳米比亚和南非。其中大约一半可能用于出口。 “纳米比亚有潜力成为非洲大陆和全世界主要的可再生能源中心之一，”欧盟委员会主席乌苏拉·冯德莱恩 (Ursula von der Leyen) 在 5 月份说道。该银行认为，毛里塔尼亚和摩洛哥可能是世界上最具竞争力的生产国之一，到 2035 年，包括运往直布罗陀的运输成本约为每公斤 1.6 美元。

罐内有气体

非洲的大型氢能项目开始加速发展。其中最大的一个是毛里塔尼亚，去年该国政府与绿色能源公司CWP Global 签署了一项风能和太阳能项目的早期协议，每年生产 170 万吨绿色氢气。 TotalEnergies 旗下英国公司 Chariot 在毛里塔尼亚的另一个大型项目的目标是每年生产 120 万吨。 “这是一个非凡的机会，”毛里塔尼亚能源部长阿卜杜萨拉姆·乌尔德·穆罕默德·萨利赫说道。

纳米比亚的情况也令人兴奋，该国政府最近完成了与可再生能源公司 Hyphen Hydrogen Energy 的下一阶段 100 亿美元项目的谈判，该项目旨在每年生产 200 万吨绿色氨（一种由绿色氢制成的产品，运输更容易）到 2030 年。它得到了欧盟的支持。 “他们需要分子。我们需要工作，”纳米比亚总统顾问詹姆斯·姆努佩打趣道。

绿色氢并不是出口可再生能源的唯一可能性。英国公司 Xlinks 正计划在摩洛哥建设一座风能和太阳能发电厂，到 2030 年将通过 3,800 公里的深海电缆直接向英国输送电力。该项目可以以比其他替代方案低得多的成本提供英国 8% 的电力。 Xlinks 表示，这是一座拖延已久的核电站。尽管 180 亿美元的成本是一个相当大的障碍，但该项目已经吸引了阿布扎比国家能源公司的初始资金。

非洲要实现其能源潜力，需要避开一系列陷阱。第一个危险是懒惰。在天然气方面，卡塔尔和美国等竞争对手正在迅速采取行动扩大产量。如果非洲行动迟缓，其供应欧洲的机会之窗可能会关闭，特别是当需求转向更绿色的能源时。 IEA预计，根据现行政策，到2030年，欧盟的天然气使用量可能比2021年减少20%。

非洲的速度记录令人担忧。过去二十年来，撒哈拉以南非洲的新天然气项目从发现到生产的时间比预期长了近 5 年。另一方面，非洲石油和天然气生产商具有相当的成本竞争力，这意味着如果需求下降影响价格，他们不会是第一个陷入困境的人。以每 1000 立方英尺仅为 2 美元的天然气价格计算，非洲三分之二的天然气仍然有利可图。其中包括在阿尔及利亚、毛里塔尼亚和坦桑尼亚发现的大部分天然气（见图表）。即使在以低成本沙特生产为主的石油领域，非洲仍以每桶 35 美元以上的价格参与其中。

与此同时，随着非洲大陆转向为目前尚无电力的约 6 亿非洲人提供电力，非洲本身对天然气的需求预计也会增长。新供应的大部分可能来自可再生能源，但天然气也可能成为稳定电力结构的重要组成部分，并为重工业提供燃料。

企业和政府也在努力确保以最环保的方式开采非洲的天然气。埃尼声称，其在科特迪瓦开发和运营的Baleine油气田将成为非洲第一个实现净零排放的项目（尽管这不包括购买和燃烧石油和天然气的人的排放量）。

威胁非洲能源繁荣的第二个主要陷阱是国内安全。圣战分子已经将莫桑比克大型天然气项目的建设推迟了几年，并促使该国邻国派遣军队恢复秩序。与此同时，尼日利亚去年部分错过了高天然气价格带来的意外之财，因为缺乏安全导致其 2022 年液化天然气运输量比前一年减少。

第三个危险是能源生产租金如何分配的争议。大型石油和天然气项目赚取的美元可能会被人脉广泛的政客和商人攫取，而不是造福于全体人民。

可惜的是，该地区各国政府在将资源收入有效投资于基础设施、学校和诊所方面并不总是有良好的记录。例如，在赤道几内亚，石油支撑着世界上统治时间最长的独裁者。他希望接手的花花公子儿子以在豪宅和跑车上挥霍金钱（并挥霍其余的）而闻名。与此同时，赤道几内亚人民正在遭受苦难。根据联合国人类发展指数（衡量收入、健康和教育的指标），该国在 189 个国家中排名第 145 位。

石油和天然气公司的重组及其资产国有化在非洲仍然很常见，令人担忧。加纳通常是非洲较好的投资目的地之一，由于该国在公共债务危机中争夺资金，塔洛石油公司 (Tullow Oil) 在收到 3.87 亿美元的追溯税单后将进入国际仲裁。如果投资者担心自己的资产不安全，或者规则会被任意改变，那么考虑投入数十亿美元生产液化天然气或绿色氢能的投资者就不会这样做。

对于绿色氢项目来说尤其如此，该项目需要吸引大量资金。纳米比亚拟议的项目将耗资约100亿美元；比目前 120 亿美元的GD​​P少不了多少。欧洲投资银行的泛非愿景是到 2035 年每年生产 5000 万吨绿色氢，其中包括从太阳能装置到出口管道的所有项目，预计所需投资为 1.4 万亿美元。最大的问题是想要绿色氢的富裕国家的公司和政府是否会投资。 “言语会变成满足需求的行动吗？”行业机构非洲能源商会的NJ Ayuk 问道。

经过数十年与全球能源市场的相关性下降之后，非洲迎来了短暂的巨大机遇。为了抓住这一机会，非洲各国政府必须从以往大宗商品繁荣时期所犯的错误中吸取教训，当时投资者被吓跑了，收入被浪费了。 Chariot首席执行官Adonis Pouroulis认为，这一次大陆不会浪费这个机会。 “本世纪，”他说，“是非洲的世纪。” ■

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 20:10:27 GMT /内容/86qr5l25rh5sknasj4fvnmjcfohud7oh https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/07/18/why-africa-is-poished-to-become-a-big-player-in-energy-markets “The Retrievals”, a tale of agony and addiction, makes listeners squirm

女性们记得她们身体最私密部位的疼痛。 “感觉就像有人……把我掏空了，”其中一位说道。另一个人回忆说，她在手术台上疯狂地扭动臀部。耶鲁生育中心的这些痛苦经历是“The Retrievals”的主题，这是由 Serial Productions 和《纽约时报》推出的扣人心弦的新 播客。

2020 年的五个月里，护士唐娜·蒙蒂科内 (Donna Monticone) 拒绝向大约 200 名女性提供芬太尼（一种止痛药）。（她后来承认偷了这种药物。）接受体外受精( IVF ) 的患者被迫忍受取卵过程，在此期间一名医生用针刺穿了她们的阴道壁，“冰冷清醒”。这些女性被背叛了两次：一次是被医护人员背叛，患者称， 他们忽视了她们的痛苦；另一次是被蒙蒂科内女士背叛，她是一位自己接受过试管受精治疗的母亲。

这个关于痛苦和成瘾的故事让英语世界的人们着迷，并登上了北美苹果播客排行榜的榜首。有两个因素解释了它的成功。第一个涉及情节：有关邪恶看护者的故事令人不寒而栗，播客具有引人入胜的真实犯罪质量。

第二个原因与讲故事有关。这部紧张的、由五部分组成的系列探讨了母性、背叛和失落等个人主题，这符合亲密的格式。佩戴耳塞式耳机的人会对这些令人痛苦的个人细节感到畏缩。这就是 Serial Productions 掌握长格式音频的方式：呈现人们想听的令人震惊的故事。 2014 年，同一制片人制作了《Serial》，这是一部重新审视谋杀案的真实犯罪系列剧。在那之前，播客还是一个新兴行业。该节目的成功——它成为第一个赢得皮博迪新闻奖的播客——帮助推出了这种格式，并推动了细节丰富的调查性制作的热潮。据报道，2020 年《纽约时报》以 2500 万美元收购了该公司。

《检索》的剧集播出时间为五周，很快就会结束，但现实生活中的剧集不会。六十八名女性因医疗事故和医疗殴打等指控起诉耶鲁诊所。耶鲁大学表示，它已经改变了一些做法。然而，听众已经选择了立场。 ■

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 18:45:15 GMT /内容/iohlog8tuonin4j3u8sju20e5rcjsb41 https://www.economist.com/culture/2023/07/18/the-retrievals-a-tale-of-agony-and-addiction-makes-listeners-squirm A new treatment for Alzheimer’s offers hope—but raises questions, too

几十年来，寻找治疗阿尔茨海默病的药物似乎是一场代价高昂的白费力气。随后，2021 年，一种名为 aducanumab 的药物在美国获得了监管部门的批准。第二种药物 Lecanemab 于今年 1 月获得批准。现在， 《美国医学会杂志》 7 月 17 日发表的一篇论文表明，第三个可能也不远了。

在一项涉及 1,736 名出现阿尔茨海默氏症早期症状的人的试验中，美国礼来公司开发的多纳奈单抗被证明可以“显着减缓”疾病的进展——一项衡量标准在 76 周后减缓了 35%。这一结果成为今年在阿姆斯特丹举行的年度阿尔茨海默病协会国际会议的头条新闻，被誉为“突破”和“转折点”。这太夸张了。但它确实标志着稳定且可喜的进展。

胜利的头条新闻是可以理解的。阿尔茨海默氏症是导致痴呆症的最常见原因，是全球第七大死因，也是数以千万计的痴呆症患者或患者的护理人员心痛的原因。长期以来，它不仅被认为是无法治愈的，而且是无法治愈的。它是退化性的，从“轻度认知障碍”发展到严重的记忆丧失，并最终完全无助。随着年龄的增长，患上这种疾病的风险也会增加。世界卫生组织预测，到 2050 年，全球将有超过 1.5 亿人患有痴呆症。

与它的两个前身一样，多南单抗是一种抗体，其靶标是一种蛋白质，β-淀粉样蛋白，它在阿尔茨海默氏症患者的大脑中形成团块或斑块。与另一种蛋白质（tau）的缠结一起，这些是该疾病的病理特征。 Aducanumab由另一家美国公司百健（Biogen）开发，目前仍在进行临床试验。其巨额成本（最初为每年 56,000 美元）并未得到保险公司的承保，并且已被许多国家的监管机构拒绝。 Lecanemab（由 Biogen 和日本 Eisei 公司以 Leqembi 名义销售）每年的费用约为 26,500 美元，效果几乎与 donanemab 一样积极。它将由美国政府支持的老年人健康保险计划医疗保险（Medicare）承保。但在许多其他地方，它可能仍然难以承受。

除了成本之外，这三种新药都有很大的缺点。危险的副作用就是其中之一。所有三种治疗都会引起脑肿胀和出血。礼来公司试验中的三名患者死亡，其中两人的死亡归咎于该药物。这些药物仅对阿尔茨海默氏症早期患者有效。但在人们开始表现出明显症状之前及时诊断这种疾病是很困难的。 β-淀粉样蛋白在症状出现前数年甚至数十年就开始在大脑中形成斑块。血液测试可以测量蛋白质的水平，但价格昂贵且难以获得。目前，诊断主要是通过正电子发射断层扫描（ PET扫描，需要昂贵的医院套件）或通过检查通过称为腰椎穿刺的繁琐技术提取的脑脊液来进行。

尽管如此，围绕多纳奈单抗的乐观情绪并非毫无根据。它不能治愈或逆转阿尔茨海默病。但即使是其进展稍微放缓，对于数百万患有该病的人以及数以百万计必须照顾他们的人来说也是一个巨大的福音，更不用说政府和卫生系统了，它们将难以应对照顾人口老龄化的成本。

该试验的成功是支持“淀粉样蛋白假说”的又一证据——该假说认为斑块不仅是阿尔茨海默氏症的症状，而且是其病因。这应该有助于指导对该疾病的其他研究。由于三种药物现在相互竞争，价格应该会下降，富裕国家以外的供应也会有所改善。那么，值得庆祝的事情是：即使不是一个转折点，那么至少也是一个里程碑。 ■

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 18:35:44 GMT /内容/si883for32m89go6aa4of27jg1rl20un https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/07/18/a-new-treatment-for-alzheimers-offers-hope-but-raises-questions-too Tesla’s surprising new route to EV domination

2011 年，特斯拉表示其目标是成为“21 世纪最引人注目的汽车公司，同时加速世界向电动汽车的过渡”。当时，这很容易被视为饼干。自 2003 年成立以来的八年里，该公司已生产了 1,650 辆微不足道的电动汽车。它的第一款畅销汽车 Model S尚未上路。

今天，人们几乎同样疯狂地认为，自 2008 年以来担任这家汽车制造商老板的埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 尚未实现这一目标。他的公司是一个进入壁垒森严的行业中罕见的颠覆者，却以惊人的速度发展。 2023 年第一季度，特斯拉 Model Y迷你SUV成为全球最畅销的汽车。第二季度共交付了 466,000 辆汽车，超出了分析师的预测（见图 1）。马斯克承诺今年销量将从 2022 年的 130 万辆增至 200 万辆，这似乎不再是异想天开。 7月15日，其首款Cyber​​truck下线，这是一款棱角分明、复古未来派的皮卡。特斯拉即将公开公布其德国工厂的扩建计划，希望将工厂产能翻一番，达到每年 100 万辆汽车。

除了几乎凭一己之力重新设计汽车之外，马斯克还对汽车行业做了同样的事情。他专注于简化少数型号的制造，从而控制了成本。去年，特斯拉的营业利润率为 17%；在非小众汽车制造商中，只有保时捷（其年产量不足 100 万辆汽车）与其表现相匹配。

马斯克主导汽车行业的雄心壮志——到 2030 年每年生产 2000 万辆汽车，是当今顶级制造商丰田目前产量的两倍，并创建首选的自动驾驶系统——这无疑会吸引投资者，他们对特斯拉的估值超过 9000 亿美元。这比 2022 年初的 1 万美元有所下降，但仍高于排名第二的九家最有价值汽​​车制造商的总和。现有企业正在争先恐后地实现其产品系列的电气化，并效仿马斯克的垂直一体化生产方法，同时抵御一波电动汽车新来者，其中许多是中国人，他们都试图成为下一个特斯拉。

但现在的问题是，特斯拉能否继续保持目前的快速增长和盈利能力。 7 月 19 日，该公司预计将公布 12% 左右的利润率，大致相当于今年前三个月的水平，因为该公司大幅降价以与更便宜的竞争对手竞争（见图 2）。作为一家具有硅谷思维的颠覆性科技公司，它的优势正面临被侵蚀的危险。巴克莱银行的丹·利维 (Dan Levy) 表示，要在本十年内每年生产 500 万至 600 万辆汽车（比马斯克先生的 2000 万辆目标更现实），就需要“采用传统汽车技术”。矛盾的是，为了保持颠覆性力量，特斯拉可能需要变得更像它所颠覆的乏味汽车业务。

关闭品牌

投资银行 Jefferies 的 Philippe Houchois 指出，特斯拉在电池、软件和制造生产力方面仍领先于更成熟的竞争对手。但竞争对手正在迎头赶上。胡乔伊斯指出，在某些领域，例如营销和产品规划，他们已经超越了它。当它推出 Model S时——体积大、价格高、电池大、续航里程长——它在很大程度上占据了电动汽车市场。如今，驾驶者可以从数十个品牌的 500 种左右电动汽车车型中进行选择。经纪人伯恩斯坦估计，今年可能会推出约 220 款新车型，到 2024 年将再推出 180 款（图 3）。面对所有这些竞争，特斯拉想要快速增长将是困难的。

与现有汽车制造商“为每个人提供某种东西”的方法不同，特斯拉仅生产五种车型（如果算上 Cyber​​truck），并且严重依赖其中两种车型。 Model 3（小型轿车）和 Model Y占 Tesla 班次车辆的 95%。相比之下，丰田的两款畅销车型卡罗拉和RAV 4 仅占该日本公司销量的 18%。特斯拉要实现销售 300 万至 400 万辆 Model 3 和 Model Y的目标，每种车型都需要控制同级别汽车的 50%（大众市场汽车售价分别为 40,000 至 60,000 美元， SUV售价为 45,000 至 65,000 美元） ）。 Bernstein 表示，没有一家汽车制造商在这两个细分市场的占有率超过 10%。

而且这两种型号都在老化。 Model Y已经问世三年，而 Model 3 刚刚问世六岁，这使得它们在一个历来重视新颖性的行业中不太受欢迎。汽车制造商保持销售增长的经验法则是每两到四年更新一次车型，并每四到七年彻底重新设计。特斯拉计划在今年对 Model 3 的造型和技术内部进行“更新”，以行业标准来看似乎有些晚了。

该公司需要远远超出目前提供频繁软件更新以改进某些汽车功能或添加新功能的战略。这可能对其早期采用者技术人员的原始客户群起到了作用，但不太可能减少普通驾车者的需求。一种解决方案是为其现有产品系列提供更多选择。巴克莱估计 Model 3 有 180 种配置，而同类（汽油动力） BMW 3 系轿车有 195,000 种配置。但这会带来马斯克迄今为止一直回避的那种复杂性。

提高销量的另一个途径是推出新车型，例如 Cyber​​truck，或者一款低成本大众市场汽车（非正式名称为“Model 2”，起价为 25,000 美元），马斯克承诺将在明年开始销售。许多年。但新模式也带来新挑战。 Bernstein 表示，相关皮卡市场的全球销量为 130 万辆，规模相对较小，而且 Cyber​​truck 大胆的造型可能会限制其吸引力。尽管低成本特斯拉可以将公司的市场扩展到美国、中国和欧洲以外的地区，但它们几乎肯定会产生较低的利润率，从而压低公司的整体盈利能力。此外，正如老牌汽车制造商长期以来所做的那样，赋予区域企业更大的自主权来管理区域品味差异，这再次增加了复杂性和成本。

马斯克可能无法避免其他昂贵的行业做法。一是营销。与所有其他被认为在广告上花费巨资的大型汽车制造商不同，特斯拉依靠口碑和马斯克本人传奇般的形象来推广其产品。巴克莱银行认为，避开广告，绕过经销商直接向买家销售，目前为公司每售出一辆汽车节省 2,500-4,000 美元。随着特斯拉寻求新客户，以及马斯克对推特（他价值 440 亿美元的副业项目）的两极分化管理玷污了他的个人品牌，特斯拉很可能会放弃其中的部分节省。马斯克也承认了这一点，他表示，他的公司可能第一次“尝试做一点广告”。

特斯拉迟来的另一个汽车制造主要措施是降价。马斯克先生曾承诺永远不会提供折扣或允许库存增加。他的公司最近做到了这两点。过去五个季度产量超过销量。在多年来以年均 60% 的速度增长之后，2022 年第二季度至 2023 年第一季度的季度销量平均仅增长 30-40%。为了转移更多车辆，马斯克去年年底开始大幅降价年，某些型号的降幅高达 25%。第二季度的销售额与去年同期相比增长了 80% 以上。另一方面是利润率适当收缩。与竞争对手相比，投资者对马斯克降价的容忍度更高：7 月 17 日，在这家底特律巨头宣布对其F -150 皮卡进行大幅折扣后，福特股价下跌了 6%。但他们可能不会永远保持如此宽容。

随着各种成本的上升，特斯拉将努力在其他方面继续削减成本，特别是在制造领域。今年三月，该公司推出了所谓的“拆箱流程”，旨在通过简化甚至消除生产过程的各个阶段，使汽车“显着更简单、更实惠”。目前还不清楚他到底在想什么。尽管马斯克在工程方面颇有独创性，但之前至少有一次试图颠覆汽车制造业的尝试，即用机器人代替人类生产 Model 3，结果导致了马斯克本人所说的“生产地狱”，并在 2018 年濒临破产。

马斯克面临的最后一个新挑战是中国，这是他与现有西方汽车制造商共同面临的另一个挑战。特斯拉一半以上的汽车是在上海工厂生产的，但它在中国的特权地位似乎已不再。它被允许在没有其他外国汽车制造商要求的中国合资伙伴的情况下成立，当时中国需要马斯克为中国驾车者提供电动汽车，更重要的是，鼓励中国自己的电动汽车行业提高水平。

这太有效了。据信，特斯拉第二季度在中国销售了 15.5 万辆汽车，比前三个月增长了 13%。但投资公司招银国际证券认为，随着买家转向快速发展的本土品牌，其市场份额可能已从上一季度的 16% 下滑至 14% 以下。特斯拉现在需要中国胜过中国需要特斯拉，该公司被迫于7月6日与其他汽车公司签署承诺书，停止价格战，并按照“社会主义核心价值观”公平竞争。咨询公司Sino Auto Insights的涂乐讲述了有关当局正在阻止特斯拉提高在中国产能的努力的传言。这还是在进入日益令人担忧的中美商业地缘政治之前。

If Tesla is to sell 6m cars a year at an operating margin of 14% by 2030, which Mr Levy of Barclays thinks possible, it probably needs to avoid at least some of these pitfalls. It would be foolish to dismiss that eventuality, given Tesla's knack for confounding sceptics. It could, for example, offset part of the decline in sales growth with new revenue streams, such as recent deals to open its charging network to Ford and General Motors customers. As brands become defined by the digitally intermediated experience of driving rather than the body shell or handling, its superior software—including, one day, self-driving systems—may allow it to keep offering fewer models than its rivals. Mr Le thinks Tesla will mitigate the China risk by manufacturing more of its cars in Germany and other countries, including low-cost ones. Tesla has been by far the most compelling car company of the early 21st century. If it is to hold on to that title, it has its work cut out. ■

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 18:32:15 GMT /content/psfbr9jt4idbsua3ke930nd796elljhq https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/18/teslas-surprising-new-route-to-ev-domination Post-mutiny Moscow descends into factional murk

T WO DECADES ago Yevgeny Prigozhin , the violent ex-convict and restaurateur who heads Wagner, a Russian mercenary group, published an illustrated fairy tale that he had written with his two children. The story concerns a band of friends who rescue an uncontrollably shrinking king by blowing a magic flute. At first he grows too fast, smashing a hole in the palace ceiling, before they bring him back down to size. “It is a very dangerous toy,” says the king, who takes away the flute.

Mr Prigozhin, a crony of Vladimir Putin, long helped inflate the Russian president, for example by running pro-Kremlin troll farms. Now he has cut him down to size. Last month his soldiers seized a military headquarters in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don and drove towards Moscow, downing several helicopters and a plane along the way. Mr Prigozhin said his “march of justice” was meant to remove Sergei Shoigu, the defence minister, and Valery Gerasimov, the head of the army, or to reverse their decision to integrate Wagner into Russia's regular forces. But he added populist anti-corruption slogans borrowed from Alexei Navalny, Russia's main opposition leader, pledging to purge Russia of its thieving elite. The failure of security services to attack the Wagner troops and Mr Putin's bewildered performance during a television appearance have gravely undermined the Kremlin's authority.

Under Russian law Mr Prigozhin should face prison terms of between 12 years and life for mutiny, recruiting mercenaries, illegal arms trading and homicide as part of an organised group. According to the unwritten rules of Mr Putin's mafia state he should probably be dead. Instead, on June 29th, five days after Mr Putin vowed on TV to crush the revolt, he met Mr Prigozhin and his top commanders in the Kremlin. He regretted that they had got mixed up in a mutiny and offered to let them keep serving under a new commander. The aim was to show that he still had complete control over the situation.

Nobody has been charged with the deaths of some 13 pilots downed by Wagner. Mr Putin recently denied the group existed (having admitted two weeks earlier that it had been financed by the state). Mr Prigozhin's whereabouts are unknown. State television bashes him, but while some websites linked to him have been censored, many of his Telegram channels continue to operate. Senior military officials close to Mr Prigozhin, including General Sergei Surovikin (once in charge of the invasion of Ukraine), are reported to have been detained and questioned. Television shows Wagner arms being taken over by the army and its fighters moving to Belarus. But as Novaya Gazeta , an independent Russian newspaper, writes, it is too early to write off the “chef”.

Whatever happens to Mr Prigozhin, his mutiny has revealed the erosion of the state and the flimsiness of Mr Putin's support base. His dictatorship has so far relied less on mass purges than a consensus between power groups. His political opponents have ended up in jail (like Mr Navalny) or exile. Meanwhile he has sowed rivalries between his loyalists, making himself their arbiter. To forestall a palace coup he prevented consolidation in the army and security services and created parallel structures such as Wagner.

This worked in peacetime but faltered under the stress of war. Mr Prigozhin's mutiny was not an under-the-carpet factional squabble but a public split within Mr Putin's “pro-war” constituency. On one side stands the conformist elite, trying to keep up a pretence of normal life. On the other is a group of angry military patriots, most prominently Mr Prigozhin. Most worryingly for Mr Putin, the army itself seems split.

The public is watching: the Levada Centre, an independent pollster, found that 92% of Russians followed the coup to some extent. Almost half sympathised with Mr Prigozhin's criticisms of corruption, military incompetence and lies about the war, though only 22% trusted the Wagner boss himself. In the absence of other critical voices, Mr Prigozhin attracted attention beyond his target audience of military patriots. Many of the sympathisers did not support either side, said Denis Volkov, a sociologist at Levada, but “stocked up on popcorn” for the fight between “a toad and a viper” .

The mutiny also showed that Telegram, and Mr Prigozhin's network of trolls and bloggers on it, have eroded the Kremlin's monopoly over information, particularly among young people. While television propagandists awaited instructions from the Kremlin, the mutiny unfolded online. Less than a quarter of young Russians trust TV . Mr Putin staged a parade of uniformed men in the Kremlin, praising them merely for not joining the mutiny, and flew to Dagestan, a Muslim region in the Caucasus, for a show of adoration from his subjects there. An eight-year-old who supposedly cried because she did not get to see the president was flown to the Kremlin and presented with 5bn roubles ($55m) for Dagestan's needs.

“While it might look like Putin has successfully dealt with the uprising's fallout… the strain on the system remains,” wrote Alexandra Prokopenko of the Carnegie Russia-Eurasia Centre, a think-tank in Berlin. The absence of public retribution against high-ranking military officers who sided with Mr Prigozhin, and the praise showered on security services, which failed to prevent it, suggests that Mr Putin is too worried that purges could create rifts in the army to protect his strongman image.

New cracks appeared on July 13th. Major-General Ivan Popov, commander of the 58th combined-arms army, one of the country's largest and most capable units, went public after being fired for telling his superiors what was happening at the front: huge losses, inadequate rotation and inferior counter-artillery capabilities. “The forces of Ukraine could not break through our army from the front, but our senior commander hit us from the rear,” Mr Popov said in an audio message that was posted online. Mr Popov's insubordination made a big impression on pro-war bloggers. Igor “Strelkov” Girkin, a former intelligence officer who led Russia's incursion in Donbas in 2014, wrote that an uncontrolled disintegration of the army was “just a stone's throw away”.

What happens next depends on the battlefield. The bombing of the Kerch road bridge that connects Russia to Crimea, which Russia attributed to Ukrainian naval drones, was another blow. Mr Putin maintains that Ukraine has failed to achieve any progress in its counter-offensive. Russian commanders have defended against Ukraine's counter-offensive well ahead of prepared fortifications, instead of falling back to defensive positions established by Mr Surovikin—at a significant cost to the Russian forces. This slows the Ukrainians' progress, but if they manage to break through, it could have a greater effect on the Kremlin's political power. As one foreign military official put it: “It is like hitting a brick wall with a sledgehammer. If it crumbles, there may not be much behind it.” ■

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 17:49:20 GMT /content/5c0rmrnnnb0q7kdg56nsl2lc5rv1g44h https://www.economist.com/europe/2023/07/18/post-mutiny-moscow-descends-into-factional-murk Why developing the world’s first malaria vaccine has taken so long

O N JULY 5TH the World Health Organisation, UNICEF and Gavi, an organisation promoting vaccination, announced that 12 African countries would receive 18m doses of the world's first malaria vaccine. Mosquirix, developed by GSK , a British pharma firm, will be deployed over two years with deliveries starting at the end of 2023. It is expected to save tens of thousands of lives each year, mostly of very young children. Around 95% of malaria cases and deaths are in Africa, and at least 28 countries there have expressed an interest in the new jab; by 2026 demand is expected to reach 40m-60m doses. Why has it taken so long to develop a malaria vaccine?

Malaria, a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes, is one of Africa's deadliest diseases. Although it is treatable, the infection must be identified and the patient attended to quickly. That is difficult in the continent's many remote rural areas. As a result malaria kills nearly 500,000 children under the age of five every year. Hitherto the best option has been to try to prevent malaria with insecticide-treated nets and antimalarial drugs. But these efforts have been insufficient. Scientists have been trying to develop a vaccine for decades. Mosquirix had been in the works since the 1980s.

The development of an effective malaria vaccine has been a formidable scientific challenge. Normally, vaccines work by training the immune system to recognise antigens—typically proteins—that are found on the surface of the infectious agent. But targeting such proteins on the Plasmodium parasite that causes malaria has proven difficult. The parasite has a multi-stage life cycle, which presents different antigens at different stages, making it harder to pick the best target. It has also evolved ways of avoiding detection by the human immune system. For example, the parasite can turn off a protein on its surface, which allows it to travel undetected between blood cells. Once it has infected a new cell it switches the protein back on. All this means it has been hard to find the right antigen to flag to the immune system. But Mosquirix has managed to find a point in the parasite's life cycle that is possible to target: the stage before it infects liver cells.

Between 2019 and 2021 trials in 800,000 children in Ghana, Kenya, and Malawi found that inoculation led to a 30% reduction in severe malaria infections, and a 10% decline in mortality. Shortages of supply mean that the vaccine is for now being allocated to countries where the burden of malaria is heaviest (see map).

Although the vaccine is a milestone in malaria treatment, more work is needed. Mosquirix's efficacy is relatively low—particularly when compared with the 95% achieved by covid-19 vaccines. But a more effective jab, R21/Matrix-M, is in sight. Small-scale trials suggest it could have an 77% efficacy rate. Adrian Hill, director of Oxford University's Jenner Institute, which developed R21, told the Lancet , a medical journal, that he hoped it would be possible to bring annual malaria deaths down to fewer than 50,000 globally by the end of the decade. Slightly behind R21 is an early-stage mRNA malaria vaccine developed by BioNtech, a German pharma firm. This innovation points to a future where malaria is preventable, and much less deadly than it is today. Some even hope that the disease will be completely eradicated. ■

S PARE A Thought for students graduating from British universities this summer after three grim years. In 2020 the pandemic forced the cancellation of their school-leaving exams, leaving them to make do with simulated grades. Lockdowns and remote learning tarnished their first years at university. Rocketing living costs and strikes by lecturers have been the latest buzzkill: because of a marking boycott, thousands will graduate late or without a proper classification. At Cambridge, one of the worst-affected universities, half of final-year undergraduates are in that boat.

Students are not alone in feeling morose. The Office for Students ( O f S ), which regulates the sector, says it is monitoring finances at 31 universities. These undoubtedly include the University of East Anglia, in Norwich, which is seeking £30m ($39m) in savings by September. Tuition fees paid by English undergraduates are capped by the government and have barely risen in ten years. High inflation has eaten away at their value. The maximum charge was set at £9,000 in 2012; by September the fee will be worth only about £6,500 at 2012 prices. It is not set to be reviewed until 2025. Universities are heading towards a crunch.

By most measures they still rank among the best in the world. Britain produces far more than its fair share of highly cited research. Only America (with five times the population) wedges more universities into the top slots of global league tables. Drop-out rates for English students are among the lowest anywhere. Britain is in the top three destinations for foreigners seeking swanky certificates.

On taking office, the Conservatives saw universities as engines of growth. In 2012 the coalition government gave them a huge boost by agreeing to triple domestic tuition fees. At a stroke, funding per student rose by around 25%. The idea was in part to make it fairer, with more of the costs of doing a degree covered by the graduates whose salaries are boosted by it. It was also to help universities expand faster—while keeping quality high—without being reliant on government grants. Expand they have: the share of English 18-year-olds going to university was about 38% last year, up from about 28% in 2012. For disadvantaged youngsters, it was up to 24% from about 15%.

Today the government has a chillier view of the sector. One reason is money. Student borrowers in England enter a national repayment system that collects a share of earned income over a threshold (graduates this year will start paying when their earnings hit £27,295). Any debt outstanding when borrowers approach retirement is forgiven. The designers of this system have always assumed that sizeable sums will be written-off in this way, writes Sam Freedman of the Institute for Government, a think-tank. But recent projections suggest taxpayers will be on the hook for much more than anticipated—perhaps half of all that students have recently borrowed.

One reason is that, once the cap on fees was raised, almost all universities sold degrees at the maximum price permissible (the hope had been that at least some would try to compete on price). Government tinkering is also to blame: in 2017 Theresa May, then prime minister, loosened repayment terms to appeal to young voters. But what has really hurt is a banal but crucial accounting change. In 2018 the Office for National Statistics forced the government to start booking the expected losses on student loans in the year they are issued (it could previously boot them far into the future).

Money worries compound other concerns. Education has an intrinsic value, but the government is struck by research suggesting around one-fifth of graduates may be better off financially over their lifetimes if they had not gone to university (that is particularly true of students who study creative arts). It worries that Britons are far less keen than other Europeans to do apprenticeships, or courses that require just one or two years of post-school study. They might be as useful as degrees, and be cheaper. Ministers are also drawn into debates about “Mickey Mouse” degrees and “no-platforming”, perhaps hoping to please voters irritated by woke lecturers and students.

Muddled thinking on universities has led to muddled policies. One of the bigger recent reforms was the creation in 2018 of the O f S . The regulator aims to give youngsters more certainty that their degrees are worth paying for. It puts useful pressure on those universities that have done a poor job of ensuring students finish their studies and find decent jobs. On July 17th the government confirmed that the regulator would have the power to limit recruitment to courses that fail to get at least 60% of students across those thresholds. But ministers have, over the years, also handed the O f S an assortment of other tasks, such as monitoring policies on sexual misconduct and policing free-speech on campus. This distracts from original priorities, such as the O f S 's goal of nurturing “challenger” universities to compete with incumbents. The regulator's rule-setting may, instead, be making it trickier to launch new outfits.

By far the biggest worry among vice-chancellors is the long-standing erosion of fees. These have been pushed up only once in a decade. Last year analysts for the Russell Group of universities, which includes many of Britain's best, said institutions in England were on average losing £1,750 a year per home undergraduate—this could become a £4,000 loss by the 2024-25 academic year.

Lots of universities have tightened their belts. They also seek more foreign students, who may be charged whatever the market will bear. In 2021-22 foreigners made up 30% of all new undergraduates and postgraduates in England, up from less than 24% four years before. At the start of this century fees from non- EU students contributed about 5% of all university income. Now foreigners hand over more than 20% of their revenues. Britain's economy overall earned a healthy £42bn from foreign students last year.

One study using data from 2017-18 found that foreigners were on average paying £5,100 a year more than their courses cost to run. For years universities used these surpluses to subsidise research—an activity which bumps them up international league tables. But profits from foreigners are increasingly used to cover shortfalls from English students. This year Vivienne Stern of Universities UK , an industry group, told a House of Lords committee that international recruitment “should be the cherry on the cake” for the higher education system, but it has become “more like the flour”.

Educating foreign students brings Britain only benefits. Yet relying on them to keep universities solvent is unwise. Until recently China was the biggest sending country: institutions that take a lot of money from Chinese youngsters may become less likely to encourage teaching and research on topics that might displease Chinese officials. In the last few years arrivals from China have plateaued, as students from India and Nigeria make up the numbers instead. The newcomers have less geopolitical baggage—but bring in less money. They are likelier than East Asians to fund studies with borrowed cash and so seek out lower-cost institutions. An average student from India pays about half in fees as a Chinese one, reckons the British Council, a government body that promotes culture abroad. They are also likelier to want to bring spouses or children along.

Even that source of income could be in jeopardy. The government worries too many foreign students hurts its efforts to look tough on immigration. Universities fear it might reverse a policy, from 2019, that lets foreigners work in Britain for two years after their courses end (this is especially attractive to Indian students). Britain, meanwhile, may have to compete harder against rival destinations for foreign students. Australia said this year it would let some foreigners hang around for up to five years after graduation.

All this is going to get harder to handle if British parents start believing that foreigners squeeze their children out of places in their first-choice universities. Rejection rates at the most prestigious ones have been rising steadily. That is more to do with the national increase in university-going than with foreigners. But the crunch will only continue: because of a demographic boom, the number of 18-year-olds in Britain will be 25% higher in 2030 than it was in 2020. But bigger-spending international students may become the focus of more gnarly debates.

接下来会发生什么？ The government has just tightened loan-repayment terms for new borrowers. The new rules will somewhat cut government spending on higher education, by increasing the share of their debt that future students will be asked to pay back. In effect this will reverse Mrs May's attempt to please the crowd six years ago. But the government has no stomach to anger students further by letting fees float up. In May Robert Halfon, the universities minister, said putting up fees was “the last thing I can do”, given the cost-of-living crisis. Fees are likely to remain frozen for at least another couple of years. Labour, which is likely to assume office after an election is called next year, has only just junked its long-held opposition to any tuition fees, so sudden increases are unlikely.

As money grows shorter, universities may make some useful efficiencies. But they will not necessarily shed their least useful activities. Tighter budgets could mean they promote the courses they find cheapest to deliver (generally not the rigorous technical degrees the government believes will make Britain more productive). That might end up increasing bills for government, if more graduates reach their twilight years without paying off their debts.

The decline in real fees feels like “a trap we don't know how to get out of”, says Ms Stern of Universities UK . Universities may forgo investments in equipment and support services that gradually lower the quality of the degrees on offer. The big risk, she says, is not that a swathe of universities will go bust. “My worry is that we're going back to the 1990s, where you get a system that is slowly run into the sand.” ■

西班牙的水库到 7月中旬通常已满 63%。今年这一比例仅为 46%。在近五分之一的法国省份，房主被禁止向游泳池注水。经过一个暖冬和少雨之后，这片大陆再次变得干旱。 3月，法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙启动了一项国家水危机计划，旨在减少消耗并增加水的循环利用。4月，西班牙首相佩德罗·桑切斯将水列为该国面临的最关键问题之一。

在这些国家中，许多国家的短缺因泄漏而变得更加严重。各国使用不同的方法来衡量这一点，这使得收集和比较数据变得很棘手。 EurEau 是欧洲水供应商的伞式集团，以无收益水作为替代指标（这包括泄漏，但也包括消防和街道清洁等用途）。按照这个标准，欧洲平均有 25% 的水因泄漏而流失，相当于每年数千个奥运会规模的水池（见图表）。

在英国， 金融危机使英国最大的供水公司泰晤士水务公司（Thames Water）陷入金融危机，管道漏水问题突显出来。泰晤士水务公司近 25% 的供水量因泄漏而损失（由于管道陈旧和温度突然变化等问题）。该国的平均水平仅略低一些，为 23%。这相当于每年超过一百万个奥林匹克规模的游泳池的水量。

意大利是该地区用水量最严重的国家，流失的水量是英国的三倍多（占其所有自来水的 41%）。爱尔兰和保加利亚损失了超过 50% 的供应。

欧洲的水管网络十分庞大，绵延 4.3 m km（大约是地球与月球之间距离的 11 倍）。定位泄漏源可能很困难，特别是在农村地区。一些公司正在转向先进技术来修补它们。声学系统和智能传感器可以测量流量和压力，几乎实时识别问题。安装在无人机上的热成像摄像机可以查明地下泄漏点。

长期以来，自来水公司在日常维护方面的投资不足；欧洲部分水管网络已有 50 多年的历史。一些政府目前正在实施长期水计划，希望能取得与丹麦、德国和荷兰一样的成功，这些国家的供应损失不到 10%。对于消费者来说，不利的一面是，这可能会导致更高的水费：这三个国家的水费是欧洲最高的。■
